awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Surface Information for Quantitative Modeling of the Subsurface
awd_abstract_narration:
Surface connections, such as those among channels in river networks, are important for understanding the development and evolution of landscapes, such as densely populated coastal river deltas. Connections in the subsurface are critical in understanding groundwater flow and solute transport. Preferential flowpaths, in fact, can quickly deliver contaminants to water supply wells, a particularly important problem in densely populated coastal areas. Establishing a quantitative link between surface and subsurface patterns will greatly advance our capability to predict the movement of contaminants in groundwater, thus improving access to clean water and limiting pollution and health risks. We propose to investigate quantitatively how the dynamics of surface networks create subsurface networks, and thus determine how surface information can be used to predict properties of the subsurface. This will enable us to better predict sustainability and manage water resources in densely populated deltas such as the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta, where high concentrations of arsenic are widespread in the groundwater of the upper delta, and salinity problems are pervasive in the lower delta. The models and data analysis tools developed as part of this project will be released as open source and we will collaborate with Bangladeshi institutions to disseminate our findings. 
Our driving hypothesis is that the 3D subsurface structure can be predicted by combining information on (i) the modern surface network snapshot, (ii) the surface network kinematics (i.e., its temporal evolution), and (iii) accommodation and net sedimentation. We further hypothesize that (iv) the nature of the surface-to-subsurface translation exerts a major influence on structural connectivity and solute transport through the resulting aquifer system. Our goal is to develop new methods to translate surface channel networks to obtain quantitative models of subsurface architecture and flow and transport processes. We will perform this analysis with a combination of experimental, numerical modeling, and observational approaches and we will verify our findings by collecting lithologic and geochemical data in the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta. Our findings will provide critical information about the predictability of subsurface structure given the surface channel network and its kinematics, and will allow quantification of the factors influencing this predictability. The proposed work will also further the development of quantitative metrics of connectivity of surface networks and subsurface 3D structures and flowpaths, and improve our ability to model the subsurface structure of large deltaic systems where spatial heterogeneity and large spatial extent prevent full characterization via field observations. By extending this structural understanding to dynamic solute transport behavior, the proposed research will enhance the predictability of contaminant migration in highly heterogeneous systems.

por.por_cntn:
The flow of groundwater is strongly influenced by spatial variation in the ability of subsurface materials to conduct flow (permeability). For the hundreds of millions of people living on deltas like the Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna Delta (GBMD) of Bangladesh, safe groundwater is a matter of life and death. In sedimentary deposits like deltas, high permeability is generally associated with coarser sediment, often sands. Sand is in turn generally associated with former channels that have been buried by ongoing sedimentation. Hence, understanding groundwater flow in the subsurface requires understanding how channel networks on the surface create 3d sand deposits in the subsurface. The overall theme of this project was to address this problem by developing new methods for translating information on surface channel networks into better predictions of the distribution of groundwater-conducting sand deposits in the subsurface.

In particular, the main goal of this project was to investigate how the dynamics of surface networks coupled to net accommodation (depositional space) create subsurface networks to determine how surface information can be used to predict properties of the subsurface: specifically, the shape, location, and connectivity of the geobodies that control subsurface flow and transport. Our driving hypothesis was that the 3D subsurface structure can be predicted by combining information on (i) the modern surface network snapshot, (ii) the surface network kinematics (i.e., its temporal evolution), and (iii) accommodation and net sedimentation. We further hypothesized that (iv) the nature of the surface-to-subsurface translation exerts a major influence on structural connectivity and solute transport through the resulting aquifer system. This analysis was performed at three collaborating institutions, University of Texas at Austin, University of Delaware, and University of Minnesota, with a combination of experimental, numerical modeling, and observational approaches. Specifically, this project comprised 5 main research tasks: (1) Geologic modeling; (2) Static connectivity analysis; (3) Surface-to-subsurface translation; (4) Dynamic connectivity analysis; and (5) Field analysis and verification.

Our work at the University of Texas at Austin focused on geological modeling with our pyDeltaRCM, the development and analysis of connectivity metrics, and the analysis of remotely sensed data. Analysis of numerical models simulated under a wide range of different sea level rise rates and input sediment compositions has allowed us to identify the surface and subsurface metrics most responsive to changes in forcings. We have shown that increasing channel mobility results from SLR and corresponds to higher sand connectivity in the subsurface. Both the trajectory and magnitude of SLR influence the evolution of the delta surface and consequently the subsurface, highlighting the importance of analyzing the trajectory of SLR and not only the magnitude. The results also show that subsurface structure can be inferred from surface information only for the time spans over which sea level forcing is approximately steady. We leveraged a graph theoretic approach to estimate discharge partitioning on distributary networks from remotely sensed data. A comparison to field observations showed that width-based partitioning is universally applicable.

Our work has provided a set of connectivity metrics to be used for the analysis of surface and subsurface patterns in river deltas, several open source modeling and analysis tools available for use by the whole community, and new approaches for quantifying the structure, dynamics, and response to change of the surface and subsurface of river deltas towards better predictions of where water and contaminants will flow underground.
